description:
Instance can't boot and is stucked on initramfs saying "mounting /dev/vda on /root failed: Invalid argument".
Replacing in libvirt.xml.template the line
<cmdline>root=/dev/vda console=ttyS0</cmdline>
with
<cmdline>root=/dev/vda1 console=ttyS0</cmdline>
makes my instance boot with kvm.
title: instance can't mount vda partition

comments.content:
Instance can't boot since the /dev/vda drive can't be mounted on /root.
There is an error in the generated libvirt.xml. The line is libvirt.xml.template
<cmdline>root=/dev/vda console=ttyS0</cmdline>
should be replaced with
<cmdline>root='/dev/vda1' console=ttyS0</cmdline>
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~cyril-ballagny

comments.content:
You can use your own libvirt.xml.template...

flags.DEFINE_string('libvirt_xml_template',
                    utils.abspath('virt/libvirt.xml.template'),
                    'Libvirt XML Template')

And /dev/vda1 is wrong. You don't have to place root on partition /dev/vda1. Even you don't have to use virtio... I think we should move the template files included in nova/virt/ to etc/ and install them to /etc/nova to make clear: Those templates are not usable for everyone and maybe you have to modify them for your purposes...

And maybe it's better to use one template file for each hypervisor. I don't like the if/else/stuff in the template file.

comments.content:
I run nova on Ubuntu server 10.10 i386 with kernel 2.6.37.2

I build my image with vm-builder, e.g.
sudo vm-builder kvm ubuntu --suite maverick --flavour server --arch i386 --bridge br100 --part vmbuilder.partition 

and vmbuilder.partition contents:
root 3000
swap 256

Then i boot my image with the run.sh that has been generated and  i copy initrd and vmlinuz to the nova host.
I make sure that the ramdisk is built with virtio modules.
Afterward I bundle all that stuff for nova:

euca-bundle-image -i vmlinuz --kernel true
euca-upload-bundle -b mybucket -m /tmp/vmlinuz.manifest.xml
euca-register mybucket/vmlinuz.manifest.xml

euca-bundle-image -i  initrd.img
euca-upload-bundle -b mybucket -m /tmp/initrd.img.manifest.xml
euca-register mybucket/initrd.img.manifest.xml

euca-bundle-image -i ~/ubuntu-kvm/xxxxxx.qcow2 --kernel ami-XXXXXXXX --ramdisk ami-XXXXXXXX
euca-upload-bundle -b mybucket -m /tmp/image.img.manifest.xml
euca-register mybucket/image.img.manifest.xml

and when i run the instance, i have the log i put above.

I suppose there is some trouble with my image because it works with the Ubuntu one given as example. There is so much time I am trying to make nova work...
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~cyril-ballagny

comments.content:
If you want to use disk images (rather than fileystem images), Nova
expects the disk image to have a boot loader of its own.

Just upload the disk image, and don't specify a kernel nor ramdisk
when you boot (or bundle) it and you should be fine.

--
